newsitem.title: UK: U.S. sanctions limit Cuba mine growth - director.
newsitem.headline: U.S. sanctions limit Cuba mine growth - director.

text.p: Cuba holds promising mining potential but economic growth has been hindered by U.S. sanctions against the island, Rupert Pennant-Rea director of Sherritt International told a conference on Friday.
"Once the biggest economic constraint was a domestic one, now it is an external one," he told the Global Emerging Markets Conference '96.
Cuba's government policies towards foreign investment were much more rleaxed than a decade ago, he said.
Currently about 2,000 foreign companies were doing business in Cuba.

Canada's Sherritt is one of the main foreign investors in Cuba targetted by U.S. sanctions. Its investments in Cuba estimated at more than US$200 million have made the company one of the most prominent investors on the island.
Pennant-Rea and other executives have been banned from entering the United States under the so-called Helms-Burton Law.

Pennant-Rea said Cuba's proximity to the United States represented a huge oppotunity for exports from the island and said the geography was favourable in its abundance of oil, gas and mining opportunities.
Sherritt has interests in oil and gas as well as a nickel operation in Cuba. The nickel property, a 50-50 joint venture with the government involves reserves of 60 million tonnes.
In 1994 Sherritt produced 13,000 tonnes and this year expects to produce 25,000 tonnes.

Cuban government restrictions on land ownership and price setting on the local market still existed but the government has relaxed foreign currency restrictions and was moving towards a market-type economy.

The Helms-Burton Law seeks to tighten the long-standing U.S. economic embargo against Communist-ruled Cuba by penalising foreign companies and their executives who "traffic" in expropriated properties and asset in Cuba formerly owned by U.S. nationals or Cubans who later took U.S. citizenship.
